newsitem.title: USA: Dlr closes US slightly lower after overnight slump.
newsitem.headline: Dlr closes US slightly lower after overnight slump.

text.p: The dollar ended slightly lower against major currencies after a Japanese official warned his country would not tolerate "excessive" moves in the foreign exchange markets.
During overnight trade, Japan's first official session of 1997, the dollar posted a nearly four-year high just below 117 yen, continuing a sharp rally from the previous week.
But Japan's Vice Finance Minister Tadashi Ogawa subsequently prompted heavy sales of dollars for yen, saying the government would "deal appropriately" with excessive foreign exchange shifts.
That suggested Japanese monetary authorities might at some point enter the market to buy yen for dollars if the yen continues to slide, currency experts said.

"The dollar came off overnight following the Ogawa comment. He basically said excessive yen depreciation is not necessarily what they're looking for," said John McCarthy, senior vice president for foreign exchange at ING Barings.
The dollar ended at 115.72/82 yen, down from 115.86/91 at the open and a high of 116.95 in overnight trade. Against the mark, the dollar fell to 1.5635/45 from 1.5645/55.

The greenback also posted early gains versus the mark, breaching 1.57 and approaching December's two-year high at 1.5735. But the dollar's weakness against the yen eventually helped drag it lower versus European currencies, dealers said.

"We had to wait until U.S. trading got underway before the Ogawa news caught up to the dollar and it gave up some ground to the mark," said Elliott Dix, foreign exchange trader at Signet Bank in Richmond, Va.
The dollar briefly bounced higher after bargain-hunters entered the market, but a late session slump in U.S. stock prices helped keep the dollar down, traders added.

After rising more than 60 points early in the session, the Dow Jones industrial average fell into negative territory by late afternoon. Ultimately the Dow closed at a record high of 6567, up 23 points.
"The dollar tracked the stock market in the afternoon. It gave up some of its early afternoon gains due to the stock market's tumble," Dix said.
Yet most traders still see the dollar continuing its recent rally, moving gradually toward 120 yen and 1.57 marks in coming sessions.
"Frankly, most people are bullish here. It's hard not to be," said James Powers, corporate foreign exchange vice president at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale in New York.
The British pound traded erratically, rising toward $1.70 in early trade before selling off sharply to below $1.68.

Traders cited hedge fund sales of sterling/yen and sterling/mark, as well as an early report that British Prime Minister John Major refused to rule out sterling's participation in European Economic and Monetary Union.
Sterling ultimately settled at $1.6930/40, up from $1.6880/90 at the open.
"Sterling had a tricky kind of day. There was a lot of movement," Powers said.
In other trade, the dollar fell to 1.3535/45 Swiss francs from 1.3545/55 at the open and to Canadian $1.3650/55 from C$1.3706/11.
The Australian dollar rose to $0.7886/91 from $0.7880/85.
((--Chris Stetkiewicz, 212-859-1664))
